questions.question: What is the primary purpose of accessibility features in Linux?
questions.explanation: Accessibility features in Linux are designed to assist users with disabilities, making the system more usable for everyone.

questions.question: Which command is used to enable screen reader support in Linux?
questions.explanation: The 'orca' command is used to enable screen reader support in Linux, providing auditory feedback for visually impaired users.

questions.question: What is the function of the 'sticky keys' feature in Linux?
questions.explanation: 'Sticky keys' allow users to press keyboard shortcuts one key at a time, simplifying the process for those with limited dexterity.

questions.question: Which tool in Linux provides magnification for users with low vision?
questions.explanation: The 'Magnifier' tool in Linux provides screen magnification, aiding users with low vision by enlarging text and images.

questions.question: How can you enable high contrast mode in Linux?
questions.explanation: High contrast mode can be enabled through the settings menu, providing better visibility for users with visual impairments.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'on-screen keyboard' in Linux?

options.A: To provide a virtual keyboard for touchscreens.

questions.explanation: The 'on-screen keyboard' provides a virtual keyboard interface, useful for touchscreen devices and users with mobility impairments.

questions.question: Which Linux feature assists users with color blindness?
questions.explanation: Color correction features in Linux help users with color blindness by adjusting colors to more distinguishable shades.

questions.question: What is the role of 'mouse keys' in Linux?

options.A: To control the mouse pointer using the keyboard.

questions.explanation: 'Mouse keys' allow users to control the mouse pointer using the keyboard, aiding those with limited hand movement.

questions.question: How can you enable speech recognition in Linux?

options.A: By installing a speech recognition package.

questions.explanation: Speech recognition in Linux can be enabled by installing a speech recognition package, allowing voice commands and dictation.

questions.question: Which feature in Linux helps users with hearing impairments?
questions.explanation: Visual alerts in Linux provide notifications through visual cues, assisting users with hearing impairments.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'bounce keys' in Linux?
questions.explanation: 'Bounce keys' help prevent accidental key presses by ignoring repeated keystrokes, useful for users with tremors.

questions.question: How can you enable braille support in Linux?
questions.explanation: Braille support in Linux can be enabled by connecting a braille display, providing tactile feedback for visually impaired users.

questions.question: Which Linux feature assists users with limited mobility?
questions.explanation: Voice commands in Linux allow users with limited mobility to control the system using their voice, providing hands-free operation.

questions.question: What is the function of 'repeat keys' in Linux?
questions.explanation: 'Repeat keys' allow users to hold down a key to repeat its action, useful for users with limited dexterity.

questions.question: How can you enable text-to-speech in Linux?
questions.explanation: Text-to-speech in Linux can be enabled by installing a text-to-speech package, converting text into spoken words.

questions.question: Which feature in Linux helps users with cognitive impairments?
questions.explanation: A simplified interface in Linux helps users with cognitive impairments by reducing complexity and providing easier navigation.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'slow keys' in Linux?
questions.explanation: 'Slow keys' introduce a delay before a key press is registered, helping users with tremors or limited dexterity.

questions.question: How can you enable closed captions in Linux?
questions.explanation: Closed captions can be enabled through the media player settings, providing text descriptions of audio content for users with hearing impairments.

questions.question: Which Linux feature assists users with speech impairments?
questions.explanation: Speech recognition in Linux assists users with speech impairments by allowing them to control the system using voice commands.
